Suppose that $Y_i \sim \text{Gamma}(\alpha, \beta_i)$
with 
$$
\mathbb{E}(Y_i) = \frac{\alpha}{\beta_i} = \mu_i, \quad \text{and} \quad \text{var}(Y_i) = \frac{\alpha}{\beta_i^2} = \frac{\mu_i}{\beta}.
$$
For large values of $\alpha$, we have by the Central Limit Theorem that
$$
Y_i \; \dot{\sim}\; \mathrm{N}\left(\frac{\alpha}{\beta_i}, \frac{\alpha}{\beta_i^2} \right).
$$

Using the logarithmic transformation,
\[
Z_i = \log Y_i,
\]
we can approximate the distribution of $Z_i$ via the Delta Method:
\[
Z_i \approx \mathcal{N}\!\left( \log\!\left( \frac{\alpha}{\beta_i} \right), \frac{1}{\alpha} \right),
\]
since 
\[
g(y) = \log y \quad \text{and} \quad g'\!\left( \mathbb{E}[Y_i] \right) = \frac{1}{\mathbb{E}[Y_i]} = \frac{\beta_i}{\alpha}.
\]

Hence,
\[
\operatorname{Var}(Z_i) \approx \left( g'\!\left( \mathbb{E}[Y_i] \right) \right)^2 \operatorname{Var}(Y_i) 
= \left( \frac{\beta_i}{\alpha} \right)^2 \frac{\alpha}{\beta_i^2} 
= \frac{1}{\alpha}.
\]
